ArticleTitle.sentence: Alpha-tocopherol inhibits agonist-induced monocytic cell adhesion to cultured human endothelial cells.

event.clue: Alpha-tocopherol inhibits agonist-induced monocytic cell adhesion to cultured human endothelial cells.

AbstractText.sentence: Antioxidants have been proposed to be anti-atherosclerotic agents; however, the mechanisms underlying their beneficial effects are poorly understood.
We have examined the effect of alpha-tocopherol (alpha-tcp) on one cellular event in atherosclerotic plaque development, monocyte adhesion to stimulated endothelial cells (ECs).

event.clue: We have examined the effect of alpha-tocopherol (alpha-tcp) on one cellular event in atherosclerotic plaque development, monocyte adhesion to stimulated endothelial cells (ECs).

AbstractText.sentence: Human umbilical vein ECs were pretreated with alpha-tcp before stimulation with known agonists of monocyte adhesion: IL-1 (10 ng/ml), LPS (10 ng/ml), thrombin (30 U/ml), or PMA (10 nM).

event.clue: Human umbilical vein ECs were pretreated with alpha-tcp before stimulation with known agonists of monocyte adhesion: IL-1 (10 ng/ml), LPS (10 ng/ml), thrombin (30 U/ml), or PMA (10 nM).

AbstractText.sentence: Agonist-induced monocytic cell adhesion, but not basal adhesion, was inhibited in a time- and concentration-dependent manner by alpha-tcp.

AbstractText.sentence: The IC50 of alpha-tcp on an IL-1-induced response was 45 microM.

event.clue: The IC50 of alpha-tcp on an IL-1-induced response was 45 microM.

AbstractText.sentence: The inhibition correlated with a decrease in steady state levels of E-selectin mRNA and cell surface expression of E-selectin which is consistent with the ability of a monoclonal antibody to E-selectin to inhibit monocytic cell adhesion in this system.

AbstractText.sentence: Probucol (50 microM) and N-acetylcysteine (20 mM) also inhibited agonist-induced monocytic cell adhesion; whereas, several other antioxidants had no significant effect.

AbstractText.sentence: Protein kinase C (PKC) does not appear to play a role in the alpha-tcp effect since no suppression of phosphorylation of PKC substrates was observed.

AbstractText.sentence: It has been hypothesized that alpha-tcp acts as an anti-atherosclerotic molecule by inhibiting generation of oxidized LDL--a putative triggering molecule in the atherosclerotic process.

AbstractText.sentence: Our results point to a novel alternative mechanism of action of alpha-tcp.
